author: By Janet Navilhon
title: Walking through Istanbul is magical
text:
Walking through Istanbul is magical Janet Navilho , San Francisco Chronicle By Janet Navilhon Published 11:24 pm, Wednesday, July 29, 2015 Janet Navilhon, of Pleasant Hill, standing in front of the Harem at the Topkapi Palace. Photo: Janet Navilhon Janet Navilhon, of Pleasant Hill, standing in front of the Harem at...

Why I went: I wanted to see this vibrant city, a mix of the modern and ancient. I stayed with a friend who has lived there for two years. 
Don’t miss: The Museum of Innocence, an artful recreation of upper-class Turkish life from the 1970s to 2000s, created by Turkish Nobel laureate Orhan Pamuk. Ferry rides on the waterways were breathtaking. 
Don’t bother: Worrying about language or getting around — the Turkish people are very kind and helpful. 
Coolest souvenir: A Turkish charm to ward off evil spirits. No religious connotation for the charm — Muslims, Jews and Christians can be seen wearing it. 
Worth a splurge: A Turkish bath at Ayasofya Hurrem Sultan Bath in Sultanahmet. Established in 1556, an exotic, relaxing way to experience Turkish culture. 
Wish I’d packed: More time. So much to see inside and outside of Istanbul. And an extra pair of shoes — walked 150 miles while there. 
Other comments: I was in Istanbul for three weeks and it was magical. I took public transportation so was able to see Turkish culture from a different perspective.
